stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 'Snowman Cave' level, focusing on greyboxing the platforming layout for several distinct rooms, including a cliff climb and a section over a void. He brainstormed level design ideas, fixed bugs related to enemy behavior and an elevator effect, and discussed his development philosophy, personal history, and the upcoming birth of his daughter.

development_findings.summary: To fix shadow rendering issues on moving platforms, Kaze plans to implement shadows as separate objects that can detect floors independently from the player character.
development_findings.quote: My idea for the shadows is that it's actually going to be a whole separate object, separate from Mario.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's level design process involves first creating a 'greybox' version to perfect the platforming and layout before adding final art and textures.
development_findings.quote: I call it the case method because I just made it up.

development_findings.summary: Kaze plans to release a public demo for Course 1 accompanied by a feedback form to gather detailed community input on game physics and camera behavior for fine-tuning.
development_findings.quote: I'm gonna have like a Google document where people can answer all kinds of questions about what they think of different parts of the physics and stuff.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has developed a highly efficient workflow that allows him to deploy and test builds on real N64 hardware almost instantly, speeding up his iteration cycle.
development_findings.quote: Look how fast n64 testing is now that I have the setup. I just click the bat and it's there. It's right on my N64.

development_findings.summary: During the stream, Kaze expressed strong dissatisfaction with the placeholder visuals of a wooden bridge, deciding to focus on the platforming mechanics first and address the aesthetics later.
development_findings.quote: Wow, that is ugly. Oh my God. We need something else. We can't have this.

development_findings.summary: Kaze brainstormed and began blocking out the main sections of the snowman cave: a cliff-climbing area, a platforming section over a void, a slide, and a final treasure room.
Kaze tuned the elevator's screen shake effect, ultimately removing the FOV shake because it looked unintentional and buggy, and reducing the overall magnitude.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes boredom is valuable for creativity and connects this to a period of his life where he lived in isolation for four years, which taught him to appreciate small things.
context_findings.quote: People don't enjoy being bored enough. They don't appreciate the value that comes out of just being bored sometimes, just being with your own thoughts and nothing else.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is committed to developing the game within the original N64's technical limitations, such as the 64MB cartridge size, viewing it as a core part of the challenge.
context_findings.quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?

context_findings.summary: Kaze discussed his adversarial relationship with Nintendo, stating they have taken down 70 of his videos, which creates a constant legal pressure on his work.
context_findings.quote: They fucking hate me. They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze announced that his and Zeina's daughter, to be named Reyna, is due to be born in five days, which will likely affect his streaming and development schedule.
Kaze is investing in his second YouTube channel by hiring a video editor, believing he has enough content ideas about Mario 64 to significantly grow his audience.
context_findings.quote: I have not tried to make a YouTube career. I generally think it would be pretty easy to hit like a million.

context_findings.summary: Kaze recounted a memory of living alone on approximately 70 euros a month for food, which led him to find joy in simple things like smelling sausage at a supermarket because he couldn't afford to buy it.

biobak.summary: Biobak is responsible for reviewing and polishing the 3D models that Kaze creates, improving their final look.
biobak.quote: He whenever I'm done with the model, he looks over it again and makes it look a lot better.

badub.summary: Kaze confirmed that Badub is the composer for the project, responsible for making the music.

zeina.summary: Zeina's primary contributions to the project are animations and concept art.
zeina.quote: We got Zayna helping with a lot of stuff. Mostly like concept art and stuff. Oh yeah, animations are the biggest one she's doing.

key_stories.title: The Ugly Bridge and the 'Kaze Method'
key_stories.summary: Unhappy with the placeholder art for a bridge, Kaze decided to focus on perfecting the level's platforming layout first. This incident demonstrates his 'greybox' design philosophy, where function and game feel are finalized before aesthetics.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze created a wooden bridge in the ice cave level and was immediately repulsed by its visual appearance, calling it 'truly, truly disgusting.'
key_stories.process: After reacting negatively to his own work, Kaze decided not to fix it immediately. Instead, he searched Google for images of ice caves for inspiration and decided to focus on finishing the level's layout first, embodying his 'Kaze method' of design.
key_stories.outcome: He decided to postpone the visual design, leaving the ugly bridge as a placeholder. This solidified his approach of prioritizing gameplay and platforming mechanics in a 'greybox' state before committing to final art.
key_stories.key_quote: Wow, that is ugly. Oh my God. We need something else. We can't have this.

key_stories.title: The Philosophy of Boredom
key_stories.summary: In response to a chat discussion, Kaze shared his philosophy on the creative power of boredom. He connected this belief to a four-year period of isolation in his past that taught him to appreciate quiet moments and his own thoughts, which he now sees as essential for creativity.
key_stories.challenge: A discussion in chat about the need for 'constant simulation' led Kaze to reflect on the value of boredom.
key_stories.process: Kaze contrasted the modern desire for constant entertainment with his own past. He shared a personal story about living in isolation for four years, which forced him to find value in simple experiences and his own thoughts, directly linking this to his creative capacity.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze articulated a core personal philosophy that creativity stems from boredom and quiet reflection. This revealed a deeper, more introspective side to his personality, shaped by a formative period of his life.
key_stories.key_quote: People don't enjoy being bored enough. They don't appreciate the value that comes out of just being bored sometimes, just being with your own thoughts and nothing else.

key_stories.title: The Nintendo Conflict
key_stories.summary: When asked about Nintendo, Kaze revealed the extent of their opposition to his work, stating they had taken down 70 of his videos. This story frames the entire project as an act of creation under direct, persistent threat from the original IP holder.
key_stories.challenge: A viewer's comment brought up the topic of Nintendo's potential actions against the project.
key_stories.process: Kaze responded directly to the comment by quantifying Nintendo's past actions against him, stating they had removed 70 of his videos. He used blunt language to describe the relationship, framing it as a significant and hostile external pressure on his work.
key_stories.outcome: The exchange highlighted the real-world legal risk Kaze operates under. It established that his relationship with Nintendo is not hypothetical but a documented, ongoing conflict that looms over the project.
key_stories.key_quote: They fucking hate me. They took down 70 of my videos, just so you are aware of how much they hate me.
